State Management

PhilJS provides fine-grained reactivity with signals, stores, and context for managing state at every level of your application.

Signals: The Foundation

Signals are reactive primitives that hold a value and notify subscribers when it changes. They're the building blocks of all state in PhilJS:

signals-basics.tstypescript
1import { createSignal, createEffect } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Create a signal with initial value
4const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
5 
6// Read the current value
7console.log(count()); // 0
8 
9// Update the value
10setCount(1);
11setCount(prev => prev + 1);
12 
13// Effects automatically track and re-run when dependencies change
14createEffect(() => {
15  console.log('Count is now:', count());
16});

Derived State with Memos

Use createMemo for derived values that cache their result:

derived-state.tstypescript
1import { createSignal, createMemo } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [items, setItems] = createSignal<Item[]>([]);
4const [filter, setFilter] = createSignal<'all' | 'active' | 'completed'>('all');
5 
6// Computed value - only recalculates when items or filter changes
7const filteredItems = createMemo(() => {
8  const f = filter();
9  return items().filter(item => {
10    if (f === 'active') return !item.completed;
11    if (f === 'completed') return item.completed;
12    return true;
13  });
14});
15 
16// Statistics derived from items
17const stats = createMemo(() => ({
18  total: items().length,
19  active: items().filter(i => !i.completed).length,
20  completed: items().filter(i => i.completed).length,
21}));

Stores: Nested Reactive State

For complex nested state, use createStore which provides fine-grained reactivity at any depth:

stores.tstypescript
1import { createStore } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3interface AppState {
4  user: {
5    name: string;
6    preferences: {
7      theme: 'light' | 'dark';
8      notifications: boolean;
9    };
10  };
11  todos: Array<{
12    id: number;
13    text: string;
14    completed: boolean;
15  }>;
16}
17 
18const [state, setState] = createStore<AppState>({
19  user: {
20    name: 'John',
21    preferences: {
22      theme: 'light',
23      notifications: true,
24    },
25  },
26  todos: [],
27});
28 
29// Read nested values
30console.log(state.user.preferences.theme);
31 
32// Update nested values - only components using this path re-render
33setState('user', 'preferences', 'theme', 'dark');
34 
35// Update array items
36setState('todos', todo => todo.id === 1, 'completed', true);
37 
38// Add to arrays
39setState('todos', todos => [...todos, { id: 2, text: 'New', completed: false }]);
40 
41// Batch multiple updates
42setState(state => ({
43  ...state,
44  user: {
45    ...state.user,
46    name: 'Jane',
47  },
48}));

Store Utilities

store-utilities.tstypescript
1import { createStore, produce, reconcile } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [state, setState] = createStore({ items: [] });
4 
5// Use produce for immutable updates with mutable syntax
6setState(produce(draft => {
7  draft.items.push({ id: 1, name: 'New Item' });
8  draft.items[0].name = 'Updated';
9}));
10 
11// Use reconcile to diff and update efficiently
12const newData = await fetchItems();
13setState('items', reconcile(newData));

Context: Dependency Injection

Use context to pass state down the component tree without prop drilling:

AuthContext.tsxtsx
1import { createContext, useContext, createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Define context type
4interface AuthContext {
5  user: () => User | null;
6  login: (credentials: Credentials) => Promise<void>;
7  logout: () => void;
8  isAuthenticated: () => boolean;
9}
10 
11// Create context with optional default
12const AuthContext = createContext<AuthContext>();
13 
14// Provider component
15function AuthProvider(props: { children: any }) {
16  const [user, setUser] = createSignal<User | null>(null);
17 
18  const login = async (credentials: Credentials) => {
19    const res = await fetch('/api/login', {
20      method: 'POST',
21      body: JSON.stringify(credentials),
22    });
23    const userData = await res.json();
24    setUser(userData);
25  };
26 
27  const logout = () => {
28    setUser(null);
29    localStorage.removeItem('token');
30  };
31 
32  const isAuthenticated = () => user() !== null;
33 
34  return (
35    <AuthContext.Provider value={{ user, login, logout, isAuthenticated }}>
36      {props.children}
37    </AuthContext.Provider>
38  );
39}
40 
41// Consumer hook
42function useAuth() {
43  const ctx = useContext(AuthContext);
44  if (!ctx) throw new Error('useAuth must be used within AuthProvider');
45  return ctx;
46}
47 
48// Usage in components
49function UserProfile() {
50  const { user, logout } = useAuth();
51 
52  return (
53    <Show when={user()}>
54      {(u) => (
55        <div>
56          <span>Welcome, {u.name}</span>
57          <button onClick={logout}>Logout</button>
58        </div>
59      )}
60    </Show>
61  );
62}

Global State Patterns

Singleton Store

For truly global state, create a singleton store outside components:

appStore.tstypescript
1// stores/appStore.ts
2import { createStore, createRoot } from 'philjs-core';
3 
4interface AppStore {
5  theme: 'light' | 'dark';
6  sidebarOpen: boolean;
7  notifications: Notification[];
8}
9 
10// Create store in a reactive root so it persists
11const { state, actions } = createRoot(() => {
12  const [state, setState] = createStore<AppStore>({
13    theme: 'light',
14    sidebarOpen: true,
15    notifications: [],
16  });
17 
18  const actions = {
19    toggleTheme: () => {
20      setState('theme', t => t === 'light' ? 'dark' : 'light');
21    },
22    toggleSidebar: () => {
23      setState('sidebarOpen', open => !open);
24    },
25    addNotification: (notification: Notification) => {
26      setState('notifications', n => [...n, notification]);
27    },
28    dismissNotification: (id: string) => {
29      setState('notifications', n => n.filter(x => x.id !== id));
30    },
31  };
32 
33  return { state, actions };
34});
35 
36export { state as appState, actions as appActions };
37 
38// Usage in any component
39import { appState, appActions } from './stores/appStore';
40 
41function Sidebar() {
42  return (
43    <aside class={appState.sidebarOpen ? 'open' : 'closed'}>
44      {/* ... */}
45    </aside>
46  );
47}
48 
49function ThemeToggle() {
50  return (
51    <button onClick={appActions.toggleTheme}>
52      {appState.theme === 'light' ? 'Dark' : 'Light'} Mode
53    </button>
54  );
55}

Entity Store Pattern

entityStore.tstypescript
1// stores/entityStore.ts
2import { createStore } from 'philjs-core';
3 
4interface Entity {
5  id: string;
6  [key: string]: any;
7}
8 
9function createEntityStore<T extends Entity>() {
10  const [store, setStore] = createStore<{
11    byId: Record<string, T>;
12    ids: string[];
13    loading: boolean;
14    error: string | null;
15  }>({
16    byId: {},
17    ids: [],
18    loading: false,
19    error: null,
20  });
21 
22  return {
23    // Selectors
24    getById: (id: string) => store.byId[id],
25    getAll: () => store.ids.map(id => store.byId[id]),
26    isLoading: () => store.loading,
27    getError: () => store.error,
28 
29    // Actions
30    setMany: (entities: T[]) => {
31      const byId: Record<string, T> = {};
32      const ids: string[] = [];
33      entities.forEach(e => {
34        byId[e.id] = e;
35        ids.push(e.id);
36      });
37      setStore({ byId, ids, loading: false, error: null });
38    },
39 
40    upsert: (entity: T) => {
41      setStore('byId', entity.id, entity);
42      if (!store.ids.includes(entity.id)) {
43        setStore('ids', ids => [...ids, entity.id]);
44      }
45    },
46 
47    remove: (id: string) => {
48      setStore('ids', ids => ids.filter(i => i !== id));
49      setStore('byId', id, undefined as any);
50    },
51 
52    setLoading: (loading: boolean) => setStore('loading', loading),
53    setError: (error: string | null) => setStore('error', error),
54  };
55}
56 
57// Usage
58const usersStore = createEntityStore<User>();
59 
60// Fetch and populate
61async function fetchUsers() {
62  usersStore.setLoading(true);
63  try {
64    const users = await api.getUsers();
65    usersStore.setMany(users);
66  } catch (e) {
67    usersStore.setError(e.message);
68  }
69}

Async State with Resources

Use createResource for async data fetching with built-in loading and error states:

UserProfile.tsxtsx
1import { createResource, createSignal, Suspense, ErrorBoundary } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Fetch function
4const fetchUser = async (id: string): Promise<User> => {
5  const res = await fetch(`/api/users/${id}`);
6  if (!res.ok) throw new Error('Failed to fetch user');
7  return res.json();
8};
9 
10function UserProfile() {
11  const [userId, setUserId] = createSignal('1');
12 
13  // Resource automatically refetches when userId changes
14  const [user, { refetch, mutate }] = createResource(userId, fetchUser);
15 
16  return (
17    <div>
18      <select onChange={(e) => setUserId(e.target.value)}>
19        <option value="1">User 1</option>
20        <option value="2">User 2</option>
21      </select>
22 
23      <Suspense fallback={<div>Loading...</div>}>
24        <ErrorBoundary fallback={(err) => <div>Error: {err.message}</div>}>
25          <Show when={user()}>
26            {(u) => (
27              <div>
28                <h2>{u.name}</h2>
29                <p>{u.email}</p>
30                <button onClick={refetch}>Refresh</button>
31              </div>
32            )}
33          </Show>
34        </ErrorBoundary>
35      </Suspense>
36    </div>
37  );
38}

Optimistic Updates

OptimisticUpdate.tsxtsx
1import { createResource } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function TodoItem({ todo }: { todo: Todo }) {
4  const [, { mutate }] = createResource(() => todo);
5 
6  const toggleComplete = async () => {
7    // Optimistically update the UI
8    const previous = todo;
9    mutate({ ...todo, completed: !todo.completed });
10 
11    try {
12      await api.updateTodo(todo.id, { completed: !todo.completed });
13    } catch (e) {
14      // Rollback on error
15      mutate(previous);
16      toast.error('Failed to update todo');
17    }
18  };
19 
20  return (
21    <label>
22      <input
23        type="checkbox"
24        checked={todo.completed}
25        onChange={toggleComplete}
26      />
27      {todo.text}
28    </label>
29  );
30}

State Machines

For complex UI logic, use state machines to make state transitions explicit:

StateMachine.tsxtsx
1import { createSignal, createMemo } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3type FetchState<T> =
4  | { status: 'idle' }
5  | { status: 'loading' }
6  | { status: 'success'; data: T }
7  | { status: 'error'; error: Error };
8 
9function createFetchMachine<T>(fetcher: () => Promise<T>) {
10  const [state, setState] = createSignal<FetchState<T>>({ status: 'idle' });
11 
12  const execute = async () => {
13    setState({ status: 'loading' });
14    try {
15      const data = await fetcher();
16      setState({ status: 'success', data });
17    } catch (error) {
18      setState({ status: 'error', error: error as Error });
19    }
20  };
21 
22  const reset = () => setState({ status: 'idle' });
23 
24  // Derived states
25  const isIdle = createMemo(() => state().status === 'idle');
26  const isLoading = createMemo(() => state().status === 'loading');
27  const isSuccess = createMemo(() => state().status === 'success');
28  const isError = createMemo(() => state().status === 'error');
29  const data = createMemo(() =>
30    state().status === 'success' ? state().data : undefined
31  );
32  const error = createMemo(() =>
33    state().status === 'error' ? state().error : undefined
34  );
35 
36  return {
37    state,
38    execute,
39    reset,
40    isIdle,
41    isLoading,
42    isSuccess,
43    isError,
44    data,
45    error,
46  };
47}
48 
49// Usage
50function DataComponent() {
51  const machine = createFetchMachine(() => fetch('/api/data').then(r => r.json()));
52 
53  return (
54    <div>
55      <Switch>
56        <Match when={machine.isIdle()}>
57          <button onClick={machine.execute}>Load Data</button>
58        </Match>
59        <Match when={machine.isLoading()}>
60          <Spinner />
61        </Match>
62        <Match when={machine.isError()}>
63          <div>
64            Error: {machine.error()?.message}
65            <button onClick={machine.execute}>Retry</button>
66          </div>
67        </Match>
68        <Match when={machine.isSuccess()}>
69          <DataDisplay data={machine.data()} />
70        </Match>
71      </Switch>
72    </div>
73  );
74}
i

Best Practices

  • Keep signals as the source of truth, derive everything else
  • Use stores for complex nested state
  • Use context for dependency injection, not global state
  • Prefer composition over complex single stores
  • Consider state machines for complex UI flows
